questions.text: 50 year old woman with T2DM is brought by her family due to strange behaviour. Her daughter tells that she noticed that her mother on her wedding was applying makeup only to the left side of her face and eats food from only the left  half of her plate. When asked to copy simple shapes such as a triangle, square, and circle her drawings are incomplete and poorly organized. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Right parietal lobe 

Damage to the right (non-dominant) parietal lobe causes left-sided hemineglect and constructional apraxia—patients ignore the left side of their body/space and have difficulty copying shapes or arranging objects.

The left parietal lobe is more associated with language and calculation (dominant hemisphere), while temporal lobes primarily affect memory and auditory processing rather than spatial attention or visuoconstruction.

questions.text: A 60 -year-old retired banker and right-handed man is brought with complaints of speech difficulties. He speaks fluently and with normal grammar, and appears to understand both verbal and written commands. However, when asked to repeat phrases, he is unable to do so. His naming and reading comprehension are intact. Which of the following regions is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Arcuate fasciculus

The key word is that patient can understand everything but cannot repeat. Repetition of understood knowledge is function of arcus fasiculus. Hence the patient is having conduction aphasia. 

Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the pathway that connects Broca's area and Wernicke’s area. People with conduction aphasia have fluent speech but have difficulty with repetition and making corrections to their speech, often with phonemic paraphasias (incorrect sounds or words). \

Angular gyrus lesion on left side ( dominant side) cuses Gerstmann Syndrome

  1. Agraphia – inability to write

  2. Acalculia – inability to perform arithmetic

  3. Finger agnosia – can't distinguish fingers

  4. Left-right disorientation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Weber syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Vertical gaze palsy 

Weber syndrome is a medial midbrain infarction involving the cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve fascicles

It presents with:

  1. Ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, mydriasis, "down and out" eye)

  2. Contralateral hemiplegia due to pyramidal tract involvement

  3. Contralateral lower facial weakness may occur due to corticobulbar tract involvement 

Vertical gaze palsy, however, is seen in Parinaud syndrome (dorsal midbrain syndrome) .

questions.text: 65-year-old woman presents to ER with history of suddenly falling down with difficulty in swallowing. On examination patient can stick out her tongue without any deviation, and gag reflex is diminished. Ipsilateral nystagmus is noted with ataxia of limbs, ipsilateral face numbness with a contralateral pain and temperature loss. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Wallenberg syndrome 

This pattern of crossed sensory deficits (ipsilateral face + contralateral body), ataxia, and bulbar symptoms (dysphagia) is hallmark for lateral medullary infarction called Wallenberg syndrome. 

Key features supporting the diagnosis-

  • Ipsilateral signs

    • Facial numbness (trigeminal spinal nucleus/tract involvement)

    • Limb ataxia & nystagmus (inferior cerebellar peduncle/vestibular nuclei)

    • Dysphagia, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex (nucleus ambiguus → CN IX, X)

  • Contralateral signs:

    • Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body (spinothalamic tract involvement)

Other options 

Brown-Séquard syndrome causes ipsilateral motor loss + proprioception loss with contralateral pain/temp loss below lesion, but no cranial nerve involvement . 

Locked-in syndrome occurs due to ventral pons lesion, causing quadriplegia and loss of speech with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. 

Medial medullary syndrome causes contralateral hemiparesis + proprioception loss with ipsilateral tongue paralysis,

questions.text: 70-year-old diabetic man presents with sudden right-sided weakness. On examination, there is loss of proprioception and vibration on the right side of the body, and his tongue deviates to the left on protrusion. Facial sensation is intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Medial medullary syndrome 

 

This syndrome is caused by infarction of the anterior spinal artery affecting the medial medulla. It presents with contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue deviation (hypoglossal nerve). Facial sensation remains intact because the trigeminal nucleus lies more laterally.

Incorrect options 

Lateral Medullary Syndrome involves the posterior inferior cerebellar artery and presents with dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral facial sensory loss, and contralateral body pain/temp loss. 

Central Pontine Myelinolysis typically occurs in rapid correction of hyponatremia, leading to quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy. 

Anterior Cerebral Artery Stroke causes leg-predominant weakness and abulia.

questions.text: 38-year-old Formula 1 driver suffers a high-speed crash. At the hospital, he is unable to move limbs, talk or drink from straw. Examination reveals quadriplegia with bilateral long tract signs with absent gag reflex but a nurse notices that he can move his eyes vertically on command. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Locked in syndrome 

Due to high speed crash patient has developed damage to bilateral pons causing locked-in syndrome. It is characterized by quadriplegia and anarthria with preserved consciousness, and patients communicate using vertical eye movements or blinking. 

Patients are fully conscious but “locked in” — they can hear conversations (including discussions about their prognosis) but cannot respond except via blinking or vertical eye movement, often using eye-tracking or blink-coded communication systems.

Other options 

Brainstem death presents with loss of all brainstem reflexes including pupillary, corneal, and oculocephalic reflexes, and there is no spontaneous breathing or eye movement, making vertical eye movements impossible.

Vegetative state involves preserved sleep-wake cycles and autonomic functions, but no awareness of self or environment, and patients do not follow commands with eye movements.

Decerebrate posturing occurs due to midbrain or upper pontine damage, leading to extension of arms and legs, often seen in comatose patients — not associated with preserved consciousness or vertical eye movement.

questions.text: 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis with lateral rectus gaze palsy and nystagmus. Which of the following syndromes is consistent with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: Foville syndrome 

  • Patient has crossed features implying brain stem stroke. Left sided weakness with right sided 6th and 7th nerve palsy means having to select between option A and Option C.
  • Foville’s syndrome is involvement of nucleus of 6th nerve. It communicates with opposite side 3rd nerve via medial longitudinal fasciculus. Damage to 6th nerve nucleus means that gaze palsy will occur with lateral rectus of involved and medial rectus of non-involved side being involved.
  • Option C will have only lateral rectus weakness as only the nerve fascicle is involved.
  • Option B has 3rd nerve palsy. Option D has 5,8,9,10,11 cranial nerve palsy.

questions.text: 60-year-old male presents to neurology follow up OPD four weeks after stroke with persistent allodynia especially while taking a bath with warm water. Which of the following is correct about this case?

choices.text: Complex regional pain syndrome type I
Complex regional pain syndrome type II

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Thalamic infarct 

This case is presenting with the classic triad of features that define Dejerine Roussy syndrome:

  1. Timing: Pain develops after stroke (in this case, few weeks post-stroke)
  2. Location: Lesion in ventroposterolateral thalamus confirmed by MRI
  3. Pain characteristics like  Constant burning pain or hyperalgesia and allodynia especially to warm water which may be percieved as boiling water or acid. 

Option A and D are seen due to peripheral neuropathy. Option B internal capsule infarct will cause motor deficit like pure motor stroke or pure sensory stroke.

questions.text: 25-year-old woman presents with double vision. On examination, she has paralysis of vertical gaze and pupils that constrict during accommodation but not in response to light (light-near dissociation). CT head shows mass arising in pineal region. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Answer is D: Perinaud syndrome 

The patient has Parinaud syndrome /dorsal midbrain syndrome which is typically caused by a pineal gland tumor as seen on neuroimaging in this case. 

It affects the vertical gaze center / rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus. 

The classic triad includes

1. Paralysis of upward gaze

2. Convergence-retraction nystagmus (jerky eye movements on attempted up gaze)

3. Pupillary light-near dissociation (pupils poorly reactive to light but responsive to near stimuli)

This results from compression of structures like the superior colliculi and pretectal area, which are involved in vertical gaze and pupillary light reflexes. The chin-up posture is a compensatory mechanism for the vertical gaze palsy

Other options 

M. Gravis will present with diurnal variation in muscle weakness.

INO will present with impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye on lateral gaze and abducting eye nystagmus on the contralateral side

Neurosyphilis will have Argyl robertson pupul with light near disssociation as described in this patient but is ruled out due to CT head showing pineal mass.

questions.text: 60-year-old man presents with a sudden onset drooping of left eye and balance issues. On examination, he has left-sided ptosis, dilated left pupil, and the left eye is "down and out." He demonstrates significant right-sided ataxia. He is unable to move his eyes vertically . Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Nonthangel syndrome

The patient has crossed features implying brain stem involvement. He has ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia implying  lesion in the midbrain tegmentum affecting superior cerebellar peduncle, leading to contralateral ataxia.

Weber syndrome: It involves the cerebral peduncle and oculomotor nerve, causing ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiparesis (not ataxia) 

Benedikt syndrome :  It has red nucleus involvement causing basal ganglia features like chorea and tremors with 3rd nerve palsy 

Millard Gubler syndrome : It has ispsilateral 6,7 th nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia

questions.text: 35 year old alcoholic patient presents with palpitations for last 2 hours . On examination he has an irregularly irregular pulse, BP 130/100 mm Hg and GCS is 15/15. Higher mental functions and cranial nerve examination is normal. There is no focal neurological deficit. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Thrombolysis as patient is in window period
Start anticoagulation with novel oral anticoagulants

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Control ventricular rate 

Patient is having atrial fibrillation and has presented with cardiovascular symptoms. So using RACE algorithm :  First Rate control and then oral Anticogulation will be started. C is for Chemical cardioversion and E for Electrical cardioversion if patient develops hemodynamic instabilility.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset aphasia and right sided arm weakness for the past 4 hours. On examination he has irregularly irregular pulse. Which of the following investigations will be done to determine etiology of this case presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Transesophageal echocardiography  

An irregularly irregular pulse is a classic clinical sign of atrial fibrillation . In AF, chaotic atrial contractions lead to blood stasis, particularly in the left atrial appendage, which predisposes to clot formation. These clots can embolize and cause ischemic strokes, often affecting the left middle cerebral artery territory. This results in symptoms such as aphasia (due to dominant hemisphere involvement) and right-sided weakness (including the right arm), as the left MCA supplies the corresponding brain regions.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate the left atrial appendage for thrombus presence. Detecting clots with TEE is critical to determine the indication for oral anticoagulation to prevent stroke recurrence. This assessment guides timely anticoagulant therapy, which is essential in managing patients with AF and stroke risk.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of double vision and left-sided weakness. On examination he has a right-sided ptosis, a dilated pupil that does not react to light, and an outward deviation of the right eye. The left side of his body shows spastic weakness with hyperreflexia. MRI reveals an ischemic lesion in the midbrain. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Occulomotor nerve and superior cerebellar penduncle

questions.solution:
Answer is option B: Oculomotor nerve nucleus and crus cerebri

This patient’s presentation is indicative of Weber syndrome(Medial midbrain syndrome), which involves a lesion in the midbrain affecting both the oculomotor nerve and the corticospinal tract in the crus cerebri. Arteries involved are paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery.

 

Structures Involved in a Midbrain Stroke:

  1. Oculomotor Nerve Nucleus (Cranial Nerve III):
    • Function: Controls most of the eye movements, pupillary constriction, and eyelid elevation (levator palpebrae superioris).
    • Clinical Findings: Damage to the oculomotor nerve leads to ptosis, a dilated pupil (mydriasis), and an eye that is deviated outward and downward (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles).
  2. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV):
    • Function: Innervates the superior oblique muscle, which helps in depression and intorsion of the eye.
    • Clinical Findings: A lesion of the trochlear nerve causes vertical diplopia - difficulty looking downwards and inwards, noticed while reading or descending stairs.
    • Trochlear nerve damage would not explain the ptosis or mydriasis seen in this patient 
  3. Substantia Nigra:
    • Function: Part of the basal ganglia, it plays a crucial role in motor control and coordination, with loss of dopamine-producing neurons here leading to Parkinsonism.
    • Clinical Findings: Midbrain strokes affecting the substantia nigra can result in motor deficits, tremors, and bradykinesia, similar to Parkinson's disease.
    • The patient's main issues involve cranial nerve III and motor weakness, not Parkinsonism features 
  4. Crus Cerebri (Corticospinal Tracts):
    • Function: Contains descending fibers of the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, responsible for voluntary motor control.
    • Clinical Findings: Damage here leads to contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the corticospinal tract. In Weber syndrome, the lesion commonly affects both the oculomotor nerve and the crus cerebri.
    • While the crus cerebri is affected in this case, it alone does not account for the cranial nerve signs

questions.text: A patient with stroke cannot perform simple actions on command, such as waving goodbye or pretending to brush teeth, even though they understand what to do and have no muscle weakness. When spoken a phrase “Repeat after me: ‘The sky is blue’”, the patient struggles to repeat it but speaks fluently and understands spoken language. Which lobe is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Left parietal lobe 

Difficulty imitating gestures or actions on command despite comprehension suggests ideomotor apraxia.It is seen due to damage to left parietal lobe. Do not confuse with constructional apraxia which is seen with right parietal lobe damage. 

Trouble repeating spoken phrases (with fluent speech and good comprehension) points to conduction aphasia. . Both are classic signs of damage to the left parietal lobe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset of right-sided face and arm weakness at the breakfast table at 8 am. He arrives at the ER at 4 pm in the evening. His pulse is 100/min, BP 180/100 mm Hg, NIHSS is 6, and GCS is 13/15. NCCT head shows hypodensity in the left MCA territory and CTA reveals a M1 left MCA occlusion. . Which of the following is the best intervention for management of this patient?

choices.text: Rapid lowering of BP with nicardipine to achieve target BP 140/100 mm Hg
Schedule for thrombolysis after lowering of BP

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Thrombectomy

Note the patient is outside the 4.5-hour thrombolysis window ( option D)  but he is within the 6–24 hour extended window for thrombectomy for proven large vessel occlusion (LVO).  

Other options 

A: It would be perfect for hemorrhagic stroke presentation 

C: No mention of airway compromise in the question

questions.text: 60-year-old hypertensive man presents with sudden onset slurred speech and difficulty comprehending language. NCCT head scan reveals an ischemic stroke. The stroke likely involves which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Left middle cerebral artery 

Sudden onset slurred speech and difficulty in understanding language (receptive aphasia) strongly suggest involvement of the left MCA (assuming left hemisphere dominance), which supplies Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas. Thus, the MCA is the vessel most likely involved in this patient’s presentation. Slurring of speech/ dysarthria can also be explained by weakness, paralysis, or incoordination of the muscles used for speech (face, tongue, lips, palate).

 

Blood Supply of the Brain:

The brain is primarily supplied by two systems: the anterior circulation from the internal carotid arteries and the posterior circulation from the vertebral arteries. These arteries anastomose to form the Circle of Willis, providing collateral circulation between the anterior and posterior blood supplies

1. Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

  • Branches:
    • Ophthalmic artery: Supplies the eye and orbital structures.
    • Posterior communicating artery (PCoA): Connects the internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery.
    • Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): Supplies medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes.
    • Middle cerebral artery (MCA): The largest branch, supplies the lateral aspect of the brain.
  • Internal carotid artery occlusion can cause ischemia in MCA or ACA territory or a watershed (border zone) infarct between these areas.

 

2. Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

  • Supply: Medial portions of the frontal and parietal lobes, including the superior portion of the motor and sensory cortices (leg area).
  • ACA Stroke: (Option A)
    • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss, primarily affecting the lower limb (leg > arm).
    • Frontal lobe symptoms, including abulia (lack of initiative) and personality changes.
    • Urinary incontinence due to damage to the medial frontal lobes.

 

3. Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

  • Supply: Lateral surface of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes; basal ganglia; and internal capsule.
  • MCA Stroke: (Option B)
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss (face and arm > leg).
    • Aphasia if the dominant hemisphere (usually left) is affected.
    • Hemineglect if the non-dominant hemisphere is involved.
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to optic radiation involvement.

 

4. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)

  • Supply: Occipital lobe (visual cortex), inferior temporal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the midbrain.
  • PCA Stroke: (Option C)
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes).
    • Thalamic pain syndrome (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) if the thalamus is involved, leading to contralateral sensory loss followed by chronic pain.
    • Memory disturbances if the temporal lobe is affected.

 

5. Vertebral Arteries

  • Branches:
    • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA): Supplies the cerebellum and lateral medulla.
    • PICA Stroke: Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome): Causes ipsilateral facial numbness, contralateral body numbness, ataxia, vertigo, and dysphagia.

 

6. Basilar Artery

  • Supply: Pons, midbrain, occipital lobes, and cerebellum.
  • Branches:
    • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA): Supplies the cerebellum and parts of the brainstem.
    • Superior cerebellar artery (SCA): Supplies the superior cerebellum and parts of the midbrain.
    • Posterior cerebral arteries (PCA): Terminal branches that supply the occipital lobe.
  • Basilar Artery Stroke: (Option D)
    • Locked-in syndrome: Quadriplegia with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements due to damage to the pons.
    • Cranial nerve palsies (especially those involving eye movements like the oculomotor nerve).
    • Ataxia, vertigo, and dysarthria due to cerebellar involvement.

 

7. Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA)

  • Supply: Cerebellum, lower pons.
  • AICA Stroke:
    • Ipsilateral ataxia, vertigo, hearing loss (due to involvement of the inner ear via the labyrinthine artery), facial weakness, and contralateral sensory loss.

 

8. Superior Cerebellar Artery (SCA)

  • Supply: Superior part of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain.
  • SCA Stroke:
    • Ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and dysarthria.

 

9. Anterior Spinal Artery

  • Supply: Anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and parts of the medulla.
  • Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome:
    • Medial medullary syndrome: Results in contralateral hemiparesis, loss of proprioception, and ipsilateral hypoglossal nerve dysfunction (tongue deviation).

questions.text: 40-year old lady complains of difficulty in kneading the dough for past 6 months. On examination she has atrophy of right hand muscles and fasiculations are noted in thenar muscles. Select the site of lesion?

choices.text: Right anterior horn cells in spinal cord
Left anterior horn cells in spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Right anterior horn cell damage 

The patient with weakness in kneading dough is having all features of lower motor neuron lesion. Hence option C and D are ruled out. She is having lesion at right anterior horn cells in spinal cord that explains all the weakness and atrophy of muscles.

questions.text: Gait apraxia and urinary incontinence are clinical features associated with damage to which lobe of the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Frontal lobe damage 

Gait apraxia/ magnetic gait and urinary incontinence are hallmark features of frontal lobe dysfunction, particularly involving the medial aspect of the frontal lobes where the motor cortex and the bladder control centers reside. Conditions like NPH/normal pressure hydrocephalus cause stretching or compression of the periventricular frontal white matter, disrupting these areas.

questions.text: 65 year man can recognise voices of family members while talking over mobile phone. But when he meets them in person he is not able to recognise them. Lesion is present in which part of brain?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Temporal lobe 

The patient’s ability to recognize voices but not faces points to a lesion in the right fusiform gyrus (fusiform face area)

This area is part of the ventral visual stream involved in face perception.

Other brain areas related to voice recognition are  spared, allowing preservation of auditory identification.

Hence, the lesion is most likely in right inferior temporo-occipital region, specifically involving the fusiform face area, which leads to prosopagnosia with intact voice recognition.

Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones. 

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling past memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Emotional and behavioral changes: Varying behaviors due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

questions.text: A 60-year-old right-handed woman is brought by her husband after he notices she has trouble doing dishes and confuses her left and right sides since last evening. On examination , she cannot perform simple calculations, but her speech is fluent. The lesion is most likely in which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Left Parietal lobe 

The left parietal lobe is responsible for writing, calculations, left-right orientation, and finger recognition—disruption causes the classic Gerstmann syndrome given in this case. 

 

Other options 

A) Left Temporal Lobe: Lesions here often cause receptive aphasia or memory impairment. 

B) Right Parietal Lobe: Right parietal lesions can lead to left-sided neglect, constructional apraxia, and visuospatial deficits

C) Right Temporal Lobe: Lesions cause deficits in memory, facial recognition, or emotional processing

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset weakness affecting the face, arm, and leg on one side of the body without sensory loss or cortical signs. Which is the most likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Posterior limb of internal capsule

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains corticospinal and corticobulbar motor fibers; infarcts here cause contralateral pure motor weakness affecting face, arm, and leg without sensory or cortical deficits.

Option A: The anterior limb contains frontopontine and thalamocortical fibers. Its involvement causes cognitive and behavioral changes like confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and memory disturbances. 

Option B: The genu contains corticobulbar fibers mainly affecting face muscles; isolated lesions here cause mostly facial weakness.

Option D: Thalamic lesions typically produce sensory disturbances rather than isolated motor weakness.

questions.text: 70-year-old male presents to ER with sudden-onset right-sided arm weakness and difficulty speaking which started 2 hours ago. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a prior TIA. His BP is 160/100 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head rules out hemorrhagic stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Start intravenous heparin for anticoagulation therapy.

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Administer intravenous Alteplase immediately.

  • The diagnosis of ischemic stroke is indicated by the patient's sudden-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking coupled toCT scan ruling out hemorrhagic stroke further confirms the diagnosis.
  • Administering intravenous Alteplase immediately is appropriate as the patient presents with signs of an ischemic stroke and is within the treatment window for intravenous thrombolysis (within 3-4.5 hours). Since the CT scan has ruled out hemorrhagic stroke, administering rtPA is crucial for improving outcomes by restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.
  • This patient is much below the threshod for contraindication for thrombolysis which is < 185/110 mm Hg. Hence lowering of BP is not required.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that resolved completely within 2 hours. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. Based on his ABCD2 score of 6, what is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Start oral aspirin 81 mg daily alone

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Combination of ticagrelor plus aspirin

Short-term dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with ticagrelor/ clopidogrel-aspirin for 21-90 days is superior to aspirin alone in preventing recurrent stroke after TIA.

This regimen reduces 90-day stroke risk from 11.7% to 8.2% without significant increase in major hemorrhage

ABCD2 score helps stratify TIA patients' risk of stroke:

  1. Age ≥60 years (1 point)
  2. BP ≥140/90 (1 point)
  3. Clinical features (weakness=2, speech disturbance=1)
  4. Duration (≥60 min=2, 10-59 min=1)
  5. Diabetes (1 point)

High ABCD2 score (≥4) indicates high risk of early recurrent stroke:

Early aggressive antiplatelet therapy with DAPT (first 21-90 days) followed by monotherapy is the current standard of care for high-risk TIA patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about ABCD2 score for diagnosis of Transient ischemic attack?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Past history of stroke

In ABCD2 score we consinder current neurological symptoms in the patient and not past medical history of stroke. In fact past medical history is consindered in CHADS2-VASc score used in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset of right-sided arm weakness and slurred speech for the past 1 hour. Blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. He is known case of atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin with INR of 2. NCCT head shows no hemorrhage. CTA shows occlusion in left MCA . Which of the following is correct about this patient?

choices.text: Thrombolysis with alteplase as patient is in window period
Thrombectomy after demonstration of favourable perfusion with CTP

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Thrombectomy after demonstration of favourable perfusion with CTP

Explanation:

With an INR of 2, IV thrombolysis is contraindicated (cutoff INR >1.7), but mechanical thrombectomy remains indicated for large vessel occlusion if CT perfusion (CTP) shows salvageable penumbra, even within early or extended windows.

A: Thrombolysis with alteplase  is contraindicated with INR >1.7 due to high bleeding risk

C: Cardio consult for chemical cardioversion is a distraction option and focus should be on stroke management.

D: Mannitol and dual antiplatelet therapy: There is no evidence of raised ICP requiring mannitol; dual antiplatelets are not first-line for acute LVO stroke.

questions.text: 58-year-old right-handed man is brought to the ER for speaking fluently but producing nonsensical words and sentences. He has difficulty understanding spoken commands. Neurological exam shows no significant motor weakness. Which of the following vessels is most likely involved?

choices.text: Superior division of left middle cerebral artery
Inferior division of left middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior division of left middle cerebral artery

The inferior division of the left MCA supplies Wernicke’s area in the posterior superior temporal gyrus, and its infarction leads to fluent aphasia with impaired comprehension, without motor deficits.

The superior division of the left MCA supplies Broca’s area in the frontal lobe, so its infarct causes non-fluent aphasia with right face and arm weakness, not fluent speech with comprehension deficits.

The left anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial frontal lobes, leading to contralateral leg weakness and abulia rather than language problems.

The left posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe and inferomedial temporal regions, where infarction causes visual field defects or visual agnosia, not aphasia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sudden onset of vertigo, dysphagia, hoarseness, and left-sided facial numbness. On examination, he has left-sided Horner's syndrome, right-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, and left-sided cerebellar signs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer is C: Wallenberg syndrome 

Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome) is caused by occlusion of the vertebral artery or PICA , leading to crossed findings: ipsilateral facial sensory loss and Horner’s, contralateral body pain/temp loss, and cerebellar signs.

Other options: 

a) Parinaud syndrome: Vertical gaze palsy from dorsal midbrain lesion 

b) Dejerine syndrome: Medial medullary infarction causes contralateral hemiparesis and tongue weakness 

d) Weber syndrome: Midbrain base infarct causes ipsilateral oculomotor palsy + contralateral hemiparesis, not cerebellar or sensory signs

questions.text: 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness affecting his face, arm, and leg . NCCT head  shows intraparenchymal bleed in left side basal ganglia. Which of the following vessels is most likely involved in this pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Penentrating branches of lenticulostriate arteries

Explanation:

  • The penetrating branches of lenticulostriate arteries arise from M1 segment of the middle cerebral artery. They supply important deep structures including the internal capsule, putamen, and caudate nucleus.
  • The described pure motor hemiparesis is a classic lacunar syndrome resulting from occlusion of a lenticulostriate artery affecting the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
  • Lacunar strokes result from occlusion of small penetrating arteries and typically cause distinct clinical syndromes like pure motor stroke described in stem of this question.
